column9: is the capital and largest city of Honduras along with its twin sister
column10: Comayagüela.Claimed on 29 September 1578 by the Spaniards
column11: Tegucigalpa became the country's capital on October 30
column14: when he moved the capital from Comayagua. The Constitution of Honduras
column16: names the sister cities of Tegucigalpa[a] and Comayagüela[b] as a Central District[c] to serve as the permanent national capital
column17: under articles 8 and 295.After the dissolution of the Federal Republic of Central America in 1841
column18: Honduras became an individual sovereign nation with Comayagua as its capital. The capital was moved to Tegucigalpa in 1880. On January 30
column20: Article 179 of the 1936 Honduran Constitution was changed under Decree 53 to establish Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela as a Central District.Tegucigalpa is located in the southern-central highland region known as the department of Francisco Morazán of which it is also the departmental capital. It is situated in a valley
column21: surrounded by mountains. Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela
column23: are physically separated by the Choluteca River. The Central District is the largest of the 28 municipalities in the Francisco Morazán department.Tegucigalpa is Honduras' largest and most populous city as well as the nation's political and administrative center.  Tegucigalpa is host to 25 foreign embassies and 16 consulates. It is the home base of several state-owned entities such as ENEE and Hondutel
column24: the national energy and telecommunications companies
column25: respectively.  The city is also home to the country's most important public university
column26: the National Autonomous University of Honduras
column27: as well as the national soccer team.  The capital's international airport
column29: is known for its extremely short runway and the unusual maneuvers pilots must undertake upon landing or taking off to avoid the nearby mountains.The Central District Mayor's Office (Alcaldia Municipal del Distrito Central) is the city's governing body
column30: headed by a mayor and 10 aldermen forming the Municipal Corporation (Corporación Municipal).  Being the department's seat as well
column31: the governor's office of Francisco Morazán is also located in the capital.  In 2008
column32: the city operated on an approved budget of 1.555 billion lempiras (US$82
column35: the city government reported a revenue of 1.955 billion lempiras (US$103
column38: more than any other capital city in Central America except Panama City.

column1: Tegucigalpa's infrastructure has not kept up with its population growth.  Deficient urban planning
column2: densely condensed urbanization
column3: and poverty are ongoing problems.  Heavily congested roadways where road infrastructure is unable to efficiently handle over 400
column4: 000 vehicles create havoc on a daily basis. Both national and local governments have taken steps to improve and expand infrastructure as well as to reduce poverty in the city.

column1: == Etymology ==
Most sources indicate the origin and meaning of the word Tegucigalpa is derived from the Nahuatl language.  The most widely accepted version suggests that it comes from the Nahuatl word Taguz-galpa
column2: which means "hills of silver"
column3: but this interpretation is uncertain since the natives who occupied the region at time were unaware of the existence of mineral deposits in the area.

column1: Another source suggests that Tegucigalpa derives from another language in which it means painted rocks
column2: as explained by Leticia Oyuela in her book Minimum History of Tegucigalpa.  Other theories indicate it may derive from the term Togogalpa
column3: which refers to tototi (small green parrot
column4: in Nahuatl) and Toncontín
column5: a small town near Tegucigalpa (toncotín was a Mexican dance of Nahuatl origin).In Mexico
column6: it is believed the word Tegucigalpa is from the Nahuatl word Tecuztlicallipan
column7: meaning "place of residence of the noble" or Tecuhtzincalpan
column8: meaning "place on the home of the beloved master".Honduran philologist Alberto de Jesús Membreño
column9: in his book Indigenous Toponymies of Central America
column10: states that Tegucigalpa is a Nahuatl word meaning "in the homes of the sharp stones" and rules out the traditional meaning "hills of silver" arguing that Taguzgalpa was the name of the ancient eastern zone of Honduras.

column1: == History ==
Tegucigalpa was founded by Spanish settlers as Real de Minas de San Miguel de Tegucigalpa on September 29
column2: 1578 on the site of an existing native settlement of the Lenca and Tolupans.  The first mayor of Tegucigalpa was Juan de la Cueva
column3: who took office in 1579.  The Dolores Church (1735)
column4: the San Miguel Cathedral (1765)
column5: the Casa de la Moneda (1780)
column6: and the Immaculate Conception Church (1788) were some of the first important buildings constructed.Almost 200 years later
column9: this mining town became Real Villa de San Miguel de Tegucigalpa y Heredia under the rule of Alonso Fernández de Heredia
column10: then-acting governor of Honduras.  The late 18th and early 19th centuries saw disruption in Tegucigalpa's local government
column11: from being extinguished in 1788 to becoming part of Comayagua in 1791 to returning to self-city governance in 1817.In 1817
column12: then-mayor Narciso Mallol started the construction of the first bridge
column14: connecting both sides of the Choluteca River.  Upon completion four years later
column15: it linked Tegucigalpa with her neighbor city of Comayagüela.  In 1821
column16: Tegucigalpa legally became a city.  In 1824
column17: the first Congress of the Republic of Honduras declared Tegucigalpa and Comayagua
column18: then the two most important cities in the country
column19: to alternate as capital of the country.After October 1838
column20: following Honduras' independence as a single republic
column21: the capital continued to switch back and forth between Tegucigalpa and Comayagua until October 30
column23: when Tegucigalpa was declared the permanent capital of Honduras by then-president Marco Aurelio Soto.  A popular myth claims that the society of Comayagua
column24: the long-time colonial capital of Honduras
column25: publicly disliked the wife of President Soto
column26: who took revenge by moving the capital to Tegucigalpa. A more likely theory is that the change took place because President Soto was an important partner of the Rosario Mining Company
column28: whose operations were based in San Juancito
column30: and he needed to be close to his personal interests.By 1898
column31: it was decided that both Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela
column32: being neighbor cities on the banks of the Choluteca River
column34: but with separate names and separate local governments.  During this period
column35: both cities had a population of about 40

column2: Tegucigalpa continued to grow reaching a population of over 250
column3: 000 people
column4: giving way to what would become one of the biggest neighborhoods in the city
column5: the Colonia Kennedy; the nation's autonomous university
column6: the UNAH; and the construction of the Honduras Maya Hotel.  It still remained relatively small and provincial until the 1970s

column8: several avenues
column9: traffic overpasses
column10: and large buildings were erected

column12: lacking the enforcement of city planning and zoning laws
column13: it led to highly disorganized urbanization.  This lack of proper urbanization as the population has grown is evident on the surrounding slopes of the several hills in the city where some of the city's most impoverished neighborhoods have prevailed.On October 30
column16: along with the rest of Honduras.  For five days
column17: Mitch pounded the country creating devastating landslides and floods
column18: causing the death of thousands as well as heavy deforestation and the destruction of thousands of homes.  A portion of Comayagüela was destroyed along with several neighborhoods on both sides of the Honduran capital. After the hurricane
column19: infrastructure in Tegucigalpa was severely damaged.  Even 12 years later
column20: remnants of Hurricane Mitch were still visible
column21: especially along the banks of the Choluteca River.Today
column22: Tegucigalpa continues to sprawl far beyond its former colonial core: towards the east
column24: creating a large but disorganized metropolis.  In an effort to modernize the capital
column25: increase its infrastructure and improve the quality of life of its inhabitants
column26: the administration has passed several ordinances and projects to turn the city around within the upcoming years.

column1: == Geography ==
Tegucigalpa is located on a chain of mountains with elevations of 975 metres (3
column2: 199 ft) at its lowest points and 1
column3: 463 metres (4
column4: 800 ft) at its highest suburban areas.  Like most of the interior highlands of Honduras
column5: the majority of Tegucigalpa's current area was occupied by open woodland.  The area surrounding the city continues to be open woodland supporting pine forest interspersed with some oak
column6: scrub
column7: and grassy clearings as well as needle leaf evergreen and broadleaf deciduous forest.

column1: The metropolitan area of both Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela covers a total area of 201 square kilometers (77.6 sq mi) while the entire Municipality of the Central District covers a total area of 1
column2: 396 square kilometers (539.1 sq mi).  Geological faults that are a threat to the neighborhoods on and below the hill have been identified in the District's high regions surrounding the capital.The Choluteca River
column3: which crosses the city from south to north
column4: physically separates Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela.  El Picacho Hill
column5: a rugged mountain of moderate height
column6: rises above the downtown area; several neighborhoods
column7: both upscale residential and lower income
column8: are located on its slopes. The city consists of gentle hills
column9: and the ring of mountains surrounding the city tends to trap pollution. During the dry season
column10: a dense cloud of smog lingers in the basin until the first rains fall.

column1: Tucked into a valley and bisected by a river
column2: Tegucigalpa is prone to flooding during the rainy season
column3: as experienced to the fullest during Hurricane Mitch and to a lesser degree every year during the rainy season.  Despite being several thousand feet above sea level
column4: the city lacks an efficient flood control system
column5: including canals and sewerage powerful enough to channel rainwater back into the river to flow down to the ocean.  The river itself is a threat since it isn't deep enough below the streets
column6: nor are there levees high enough to prevent it from breaking out.  There are more than 100 neighborhoods deemed zones of high risk
column7: several of them ruled out as uninhabitable in their entirety.There is a reservoir
column8: known as Embalse Los Laureles
column9: west of the city providing 30 percent of the city's water supply as well as a water treatment plant south of the city about 7.3 kilometres (4.5 mi) from the airport; part of the Concepción Reservoir just 6 kilometres (3.7 mi) southwest of the water plant.

column1: The Central District shares borders with 13 other municipalities of Francisco Morazán: (to the north) Cedros and Talanga; (south) Ojojona
column2: Santa Ana
column3: San Buenaventura and Maraita; (east) San Juan de Flores
column4: Villa de San Francisco
column5: Santa Lucía
column6: Valle de Ángeles
column8: and Tatumbla; (and to the west) Lepaterique.  It is also bordered on the west by two municipalities of the Comayagua Department
column9: Villa de San Antonio and Lamaní
column10: with the latter exactly at the quadripoint where the Central District
column12: Villa de San Antonio and Lamaní all meet.

column1: === Climate ===
Tegucigalpa features a more moderate form of a tropical wet and dry climate. Of the major Central American cities
column2: Tegucigalpa's climate is among the most pleasant due to its high altitude.  Like much of central Honduras
column3: the city has a tropical climate
column4: though tempered by the altitude—meaning less humid than the lower valleys and the coastal regions—with even temperatures averaging between 19 °C (66 °F) and 23 °C (73 °F) degrees.The months of December and January are coolest
column5: with an average min/ low temperature of 14 °C (57 °F); whereas March and April—popularly associated with Holy Week's holidays—are hottest and temperatures can reach up to 40 °C (104 °F) degrees on the hottest day.  The dry season lasts from November through April and the rainy season from May through October.  There is an average of 107 rainy days in the year
column6: June and September usually the wettest months.

column1: The average sunshine hours per month during the year is 211.2 and the average rainy days per month is 8.9.  The average sunshine hours during the dry season is 228 per month while 182.5 millimetres (7.19 in) is the average monthly precipitation during the wet season.  The wettest months of the rainy season are May—June and September—October
column2: averaging 16.2 rainy days during each of those periods.

column1: === Hurricane Mitch ===
Tegucigalpa
column2: as with the rest of Honduras
column3: experienced significant damage by Hurricane Mitch in late-October and early-November 1998
column4: something of a magnitude Hondurans had not witnessed since Hurricane Fifi. Mitch destroyed part of the Comayagüela section of the city
column5: as well as other places along the banks of the Choluteca River. The storm remained over Honduran territory for five days
column6: dumping heavy rainfall late in the rainy season. The ground was already saturated and could not absorb the heavy precipitation
column7: while deforestation and debris left by the hurricane led to catastrophic flooding throughout widespread regions of the country
column8: especially in Tegucigalpa.The heavy rain caused flash floods of Choluteca's tributaries
column9: and the swollen river overflowed its banks
column10: tearing down entire neighborhoods and bridges across the ravaged city. The rainfall also triggered massive landslides around El Berrinche Hill
column11: close to the downtown area. These landslides destroyed most of the Soto neighborhood
column12: and debris flowed into the river
column13: forming a dam. The dam clogged the waters of the river and many of the low-lying areas of Comayagüela were submerged; historic buildings located along Calle Real were either completely destroyed or so badly damaged that repair was futile.

column1: == Cityscape ==
Situated in a valley and surrounded by mountain ranges
column2: Tegucigalpa is hilly with several elevations and few flat areas.  The city is also highly disorganized
column3: particularly around its oldest districts. It has seen a rapid growth in the last 30 years
column4: and only until recently has the government passed certain laws to establish city planning and zoning rules.  Surface roads can be narrow with the most important avenues carrying no more than two or three lanes running in each direction
column5: adding to the problem of heavy traffic congestion.  Several of the main boulevards have been equipped with interchanges
column6: overpasses and underpasses
column7: allowing for sections of controlled-access highways
column8: but considering that even the city's beltway does not entirely circle the city
column9: the roads are generally limited-access.  Intense webs of electrical and telephone lines above the streets are a common sight in the capital
column10: and in virtually all Honduran cities
column11: since implementation of underground utility lines has only been adopted in recent years.

column1: === Around the city ===

The metropolitan area of Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela is officially divided into barrios and colonias and there are 892 of them.  Colonias represent relatively recent 20th-century middle class residential suburbs
column2: some known as residenciales for their upper income development
column3: and these are continuously spreading while the barrios are old inner-city neighborhoods.

column1: While the city administration divides the capital into barrios and colonias
column2: the fact that there are hundreds of them makes it difficult to define the city's different regions
column3: especially for those not familiar with the Central District.  To have a better understanding of the city's regions
column4: the metro area of the Central District can essentially be divided
column5: first
column6: into two sections: Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela.  These two entities remain separated by the Choluteca River basin that runs between them.

column1: The Tegucigalpa side of the District can be divided into five sections: 1) Centro Histórico (Historic Downtown); 2) Centro Contemporáneo or Zona Viva (Contemporary Downtown or Vibrant Zone); 3) North Tegucigalpa; 4) South Tegucigalpa; and 5) East Tegucigalpa.
1 – Centro Histórico or the Historic Downtown of Tegucigalpa is formed by the original neighborhoods that date back to its founding days.  For years
column2: this area remained neglected and run down
column3: but in recent times attempts have been made to revive the zone and bring back its colonial heritage.  Several government offices
column4: including the National Congress and City Hall as well as museums
column5: parks
column6: a cathedral and churches are located here.

column1: 2 – Centro Contemporáneo is the contemporary
column2: vibrant and modern downtown of Tegucigalpa.  This area is formed by the neighborhoods encompassed east of the Choluteca River
column3: south of the northern tributary
column4: Rio Chiquito (which confluences with the Choluteca below the Mallol Bridge)
column5: west of the beltway (Anillo Periférico)
column6: and north of Armed Forces Blvd.

column1: This section of the city is perhaps the best developed and properly urbanized.  It is formed by more than 40 neighborhoods
column2: many of them wealthy middle class residential areas such as Colonia Palmira to the east of the historic center
column3: on Boulevard Morazán
column4: which hosts several foreign embassies as well as upscale restaurants.  Other upscale neighborhoods are Lomas del Guijarro
column5: Loma Linda
column6: and Lomas del Mayab
column7: which house most of the apartment complexes in the city.

column1: The leading hotels of the city are found around these neighborhoods
column2: including within the Plaza San Martín Hotel District. These include: the Marriott Hotel
column3: Clarion Hotel
column4: Hotel El Centenario
column5: Intercontinental
column6: Honduras Maya
column8: Plaza San Martín
column9: Hotel Alameda
column10: and Excelsior Hotel and Casino.

column1: Boulevard Morazán and Avenida Los Próceres/Avenida La Paz are busy commercial corridors (running parallel to each other) and run through several neighborhoods home to foreign embassies
column2: a hotel district
column3: business establishments and corporate buildings
column4: including Los Próceres Comercial Park (Parque Comercial).  Boulevard Suyapa and Boulevard Juan Pablo II are located south of the aforementioned boulevards
column5: and they also form a busy commercial and financial district stretching through several neighborhoods such as Colonia Los Profesionales where the Presidential House is located; Colonia Florencia Norte where Multiplaza Mall is located; Colonia Miramontes
column6: among others—housing several financial institutions
column8: hotels
column9: etc.

column1: 3 – North Tegucigalpa is formed by both middle class and impoverished neighborhoods that lie above the surrounding hill immediately north of the historic downtown.  Beyond these neighborhoods sits the United Nations National Park on El Picacho Hill
column2: one of the most popular destinations in the capital among its residents and visitors.  Beyond the Park
column3: stretching north and northwest of the city
column4: upper income suburban neighborhoods such as El Hatillo sit on the sides of the hills
column5: surrounded by heavy vegetation.

column1: 4 – South Tegucigalpa is everything south of Boulevard Fuerzas Armadas.  This area is home to Colonia Kennedy
column2: the capital's largest neighborhood with more than 137
column3: 000 residents.  South Tegucigalpa concentrates both middle class and poor neighborhoods.  Two universities
column4: UTH and UNITEC
column5: are located just off the beltway in southern outskirt neighborhoods.

column1: 5 – East Tegucigalpa concentrates mostly rural and impoverished neighborhoods
column2: the result of improvised growth with little government funding and involvement.  María Pediatric Hospital and the Basílica of Suyapa lie on the side of Anillo Períferico's eastern stretch.

column1: === Comayagüela ===
Comayagüela is found on the west bank of the Choluteca River
column2: and most of its urbanization is made up of lower income neighborhoods.  Historically
column3: Comayagüela has remained less developed than the other side of the capital
column4: some citing insufficient contribution from public officials.  In recent years
column5: this western side of the capital has seen some growth and improvement such as the opening of Metromall near the airport.  With the construction of Mall Premier and City Mall
column6: the latter to become the largest mall in the country
column7: Comayagüela will be receiving another upgrade.  There are an estimated 650
column8: 000 residents in Comayagüela contributing 58.3 percent of the 120 million lempiras (US$6.349 million) generated every day by commerce in the Central District.

column1: The Comayagüela side of the capital can be divided into four sections: 1) Zona Centro (Downtown Comayagüela); 2) North Comayagüela; 3) South Comayagüela; and 4) West Comayagüela:

1 – Zona Centro de Comayagüela is the downtown area of Comayagüela and also the original founding grounds formed by its oldest barrios.  These barrios are formed in a grid street plan style.  Several government offices are located in this district
column2: including the Central Bank of Honduras Annex building and the Criminal Bureau of Investigation (Dirección General de Investigación Criminal) as well as the National School of Fine Arts housed in the former City Hall building of Comayagüela
column3: built in 1845.

column1: 2 – North Comayagüela is formed by relatively recent post-Hurricane Mitch middle class residential developments that stretch onto the northern hills of Comayagüela
column2: such as Colonia Cerro Grande
column3: a continuously growing middle-class neighborhood on the northern outskirts.

column1: 3 – South Comayagüela is by far the better-off region of Comayagüela.  This area is found south and southwest of the airport
column2: around Los Laureles Reservoir and south of Lepaterique Road (Carretera Lepaterique also known as Carretera al Batallón).  Also a post-Hurricane Mitch area
column3: it has grown in the last decade and includes some of Comayagüela's upper income communities that have erupted in the area and continues to spread out as newer suburban middle class developments are built.  Toncontín International
column4: Metro Mall and City Mall are located in this area.  Residencial la Arboleda and Residencial los Hidalgos are some of the growing upper income developments in the southern outskirts of Comayagüela.

column1: 4 – West Comayagüela is mostly impoverished neighborhoods spreading away from Zona Centro onto the surrounding slopes.  Many of these neighborhoods came to be through improvised urbanization and lack proper infrastructure.  This area prevails north of Lepaterique Road and westward of Boulevard de la Comunidad Europea (European Community Blvd).

column1: === Religion ===
As with the rest of Honduras
column2: Roman Catholicism is the dominating religion in the Central District and while at some point they made up as much as 95 percent of the population
column3: contemporary estimates as recent as 2007 put them at 47 percent while Protestants make up as much as 36 percent.  Their history in Tegucigalpa began around 1548 with the Spanish setting up Mercedarian missionaries as part of their conversion efforts of the native communities.  By 1916
column4: the Diocese of Comayagua was relocated and renamed the Diocese of Tegucigalpa
column5: and it was elevated to Archdiocese under Archbishop Santiago María Martínez y Cabanas (1842–1921).Other religious groups made their way at the beginning of the 20th century including the Quakers
column6: who in 1914 began work in the nation's capital.  In 1946
column7: missionaries of the Southern Baptist Convention first arrived in Tegucigalpa and in the 1950s
column8: the National Convention of Baptist Churches and the Eastern Mennonite Board of Missions followed.

column1: The Assembly of God missionaries entered Honduras in the late 1940s and today maintain a mega-church in Tegucigalpa with more than 10
column2: 000 members.  The Church of God of Cleveland
column3: Tennessee was established in Tegucigalpa in 1951
column4: the International Church of the Foursquare Gospel followed in 1952
column5: and by the late 1950s
column6: the Evangelical Alliance of Honduras was established.  The Prince of Peace Pentecostal Church
column8: began its ministry in Honduras during the 1960s.  During the 1970s
column9: the Catholic Charismatic Renewal Movement began to grow among the upper classes in Tegucigalpa.The Christian Love Brigade Association arrived in Tegucigalpa in 1971
column10: the Abundant Life Christian Church was founded in 1972
column11: the Cenacle Christian Center of Charismatic Renewal began in 1978 and the Living Love Groups started in 1978.The Presbyterian Church in Honduras member churches are mainly concentrated within 150 km (93 mi) of Tegucigalpa. The first Presbyterian congregation was planted 50 years ago
column12: by the National Evangelical Presbyterian Church of Guatemala.Today
column13: they are many religious groups in Tegucigalpa including a Jewish community
column14: Jehovah's Witnesses and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints that is building a new temple in the city.

column1: === Crime and violence ===
Honduras
column2: including the capital city Tegucigalpa
column3: has the world's highest murder rate. Honduras has been experiencing record-high violence in recent years.  In 2010
column4: the homicide rate in Francisco Morazán was 83.2 (per 100
column5: 000 inhabitants) compared to the national average of 86.In 2009
column6: the Central District reached a homicide rate of 72.7 with authorities recording 792 intentional homicides and 151 involuntary homicides; this averaged to 66 murders per month or two per day.  85.6 percent of the deaths were committed by firearm and 39 percent were linked to organized crime.  91 percent of the victims were men and 81.2 of that were ages 15 to 39.  The neighborhoods in Tegucigalpa reporting the highest incidence of violent deaths are poor and impoverished areas that include Barrio Concepción
column8: Colonia Villa Nueva Norte
column9: Colonia Cerro Grande
column10: Colonia El Carrizal No. 1
column18: including bicyclists; 39 percent were caused by private vehicle and 12 percent by public transportation vehicle.  In the same year
column19: there were 69 deaths reported as suicides
column20: which were most common in the age bracket of 20 to 29 and 30 to 35
column21: while 76.9 percent of them were men.Having around eight million people in the country
column23: 000 gang members in 300 to 400 street gangs
column24: most of them based in Tegucigalpa. These gangs commit all types of crimes against the local population as well as foreigners
column25: including phone call threats. The gangs also appear to have a lot of control in the cities with controlling public goods such as public taxis and they are very involved. The Honduran government does not have much control against the gangs because the government system is not itself very stable. Most of the crime cases are not very well prosecuted and sometimes just discarded
column26: but police enforcement is better in the upper-class neighborhoods and in the tourists parts of the city.

column1: == Economy ==
The Central District has an economy equal to 19.3 percent of country's GDP.  In 2009
column2: the city's revenue and expenditures budget was L.2
column12: 606).  57.9 percent or L.43.860 billion (US$2.318 billion) of the country's national budget is spent within the Central District.The District's active labor force is 367
column14: 035 are employed in the public sector.  In 2009
column15: the unemployment rate in Tegucigalpa was 8.1 percent
column16: and an unemployed person may spend as much as four months seeking employment. There are 32
column18: the most of any city in the country.  The size of these businesses is broken down as follows: micro-enterprises (73.2%)

column1: The city's major economic sources are commerce
column2: construction
column3: services
column4: textiles
column5: sugar
column6: and tobacco.  Economic activity is broken down as follows: commerce—including wholesale
column8: auto repair
column9: household goods (42.86%); manufacturing industry (16.13%)

column29: and farm machinery.  Maquiladora duty-free assembly plants have been established in an industrial park in the Amarateca valley
column31: lead and zinc are still mined in the outskirts of the city.

column1: === Banking ===
Honduran banks based in Tegucigalpa include the Central Bank of Honduras
column2: Banco Continental and Banco de Occidente. Tegucigalpa also has a number of International financial institutions
column3: which include BAC Credomatic (formerly Banco Mercantil-BAMER)
column4: Citibank
column5: Davivienda
column6: the Inter-American Development Bank (IAB)
column8: and the Central American Bank for Economic Integration (BCIE)
column9: with its headquarters located in Colonia Miramontes on Boulevard Suyapa.

column1: === Foreign investment ===
Manufacturing assembly plants (maquiladoras) were introduced in Honduras in 1976.  While their contribution to the economy remained small
column2: they boomed at the beginning of the 1990s
column3: mostly concentrating in northern Honduras
column4: but after the mid-1990s they were expanded to the central region
column5: including Tegucigalpa.  By 2005
column6: at least 6 maquiladoras operated in the Central District.By the end of the 1990s and early 2000s (decade)
column7: Tegucigalpa continued to be a focus city for the development of industrial parks.  The main obstacle to establishing factories in Tegucigalpa has been facilitating infrastructure to provide efficient access between the capital and country's economic hubs: San Pedro Sula and Puerto Cortez.While foreign investment manufacturers and exporters have focused on northern Honduras
column8: the presence of multinational corporations is evident in Tegucigalpa.  Popular retail
column9: restaurant
column10: and hospitality American-branded franchises prevail throughout the Honduran capital; such as Walmart
column13: among others.  Companies from other countries such as Mexico
column14: have also made their presence with arrivals like Cinépolis movie theaters
column15: which opened in 2010 in Cascadas Mall.  Foreign real estate and property developers operate in the capital District as well
column16: such as Grupo Roble of the Multiplaza malls.

column1: Tegucigalpa's economic challenges are tied to those of the rest of the country
column2: such as overcoming crime
column3: anomalies in the judicial system
column4: educational backwardness
column5: and deficient infrastructure in order to continue to encourage foreign investors and permit growth of local entrepreneurs.

column1: == Government ==
As capital of Honduras
column2: as department head and as a municipality
column3: the Central District seats three separate governments: national
column4: departmental and municipal.  Prior to 1991
column5: the central government held great jurisdiction over the execution of city management across the country
column6: leading to uneven representation and improper distribution of resources and governance.  As a result
column8: the National Congress of Honduras enacted the Law of Municipalities (Ley de Municipalidades)
column9: defining the country's department and municipal institutions
column10: representatives and their functions to give city government autonomy and decentralize it from the national government.While autonomous
column11: the Central District is still influenced by the national government given the territory remains seat of government of the republic.  Major changes in public policy and funding of major city projects usually reach the Office of the President prior to approval by the District's local government.The government in Honduras is very unstable
column12: the government has a very hard time providing the proper resources for citizens and forming their citizens in investing in medical equipment and education for medical professions in Honduras
column13: they also have difficulties with controlling the criminals in cities and gangs that resulted in such high crime rates in the country.

column1: === Central District ===
Legally and politically speaking
column2: the capital of Honduras is the Municipality of the Central District (Spanish: Distrito Central or DC) and Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela are two entities within the district.  However
column3: nearly all governmental institutions are on the Tegucigalpa side
column4: so for all practical purposes Tegucigalpa is the capital.  Traditionally
column5: they are regarded as twin or sister cities in part because they were founded as two distinct cities.  When the Central District was formed on January 30
column6: 1937 under Decree 53 of reformed Article 179 of the 1936 Honduran Constitution
column7: both cities became one political entity sharing the title of Capital of Honduras.The Constitution of Honduras
column8: under Chapter 1
column9: Article 8
column10: states (translated)
column13: constitute the Capital of the Republic." Furthermore
column16: states (translated)  "The Central District consists of a single municipality made up of the former municipalities of Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela"; however
column17: municipalities in Honduras are defined as political entities similar to counties
column18: and they may contain one or more cities.  For example
column20: La Ceiba is the largest city—being also the third largest in Honduras—both in terms of population and metropolitan area; however
column22: one of the eight municipalities of Atlántida
column23: is the biggest municipality in terms of physical administrative area in that department.  Since the Municipality of Tela is not considered the entire city of Tela
column24: it is not bigger than La Ceiba.

column1: There are an additional of 41 villages and 293 hamlets through the Central District Municipality.  These may be assigned deputy mayors (alcalde auxiliar) to serve as local representatives.
=== National and departmental governments ===

Tegucigalpa is the political and administrative center of Honduras.  It is also the seat of government of the Francisco Morazán department.  All three branches of the national government as well as their immediate divisions—including the 16 departments of the Executive Branch
column2: the National Congress
column3: the Supreme Court of Justice
column4: the Armed Forces and National Police headquarters—are located in the city.  Most public agencies and state-owned companies are headquartered in the capital as well.

column1: === Local government ===
City government takes the form of a mayor-council system and is regulated under the Law of Municipalities that came into effect on January 1
column2: 1991.  The Central District Municipal Government (Alcaldía Municipal del Distrito Central or AMDC) is the city's governing authority.  As established by city governing law
column3: AMDC is structured as a municipal corporation
column4: which is the deliberative-legislative body
column5: voter-elected
column6: and highest authority within the municipality.The Municipal Corporation is formed by a mayor serving as chief executive
column7: general administrator and legal representative of the municipality and a vice mayor to serve as acting mayor when required and to oversee functions within AMDC as instructed by the mayor.Ten aldermen (regidores) are also members of the Municipal Corporation who along with the mayor execute the duties as described in the Law of Municipalities
column8: including management
column9: budgeting
column10: and local law and ordinance legislation.A general manager
column12: serves as chief comptroller to manage city funds and their allocation.  A municipal secretary
column14: serves as the city clerk in charge of keeping record of all official proceedings.  The Municipal Corporation also consults with a Municipal Development Council (Consejo de Desarrollo Municipal)
column15: which serves as an advising cabinet on all the areas of issues of the city such as human development

column1: === Current administration ===

The mayor of the Central District is Nasry Asfura (PNH) who is serving his first term (2014–2018) after winning the election in 2013. He is the eighth person to serve as mayor of the Central District since local elections were restored in 1986 (prior to 1986
column2: the Central District local government
column3: known as Consejo Metropolitano (Metropolitan Council)
column4: was appointed by the President); and this is the ninth elected mayoral term since then and the fourth consecutive elected mayor from the National Party.

column1: Of the 10 aldermen serving
column2: seven are men and three are women. Five belong to the National Party while another two belong to Libertad y Refundación; two aldermen belong to the Liberal Party and the other is from the Anti-Corruption Party.

column1: Both the city mayor and aldermen are elected to 4-year terms by voters of the Central District.  Removal of the mayor or any alderman for any cause is reserved to the Ministry of Interior and Population (Secretaría del Interior y Población)
column2: formerly Secretaría de Gobernación y Justicia.

column1: === Law enforcement ===
Law enforcement in the city is the responsibility of the National Police of Honduras
column2: the nationwide police force.  The National Police maintains its headquarters in the Central District in Colonia Casamata.  The Metropolitan Police Headquarters No. 1 (Jefatura Metropolitana No. 1) is the police department in charge of law and order in the city.  It operates seven police districts throughout the metropolitan area.  These are Police District 1-1 El Edén
column3: Police District 1–2 El Mandén
column4: Police District 1–3 San Miguel
column5: Police District 1–4 Kennedy
column6: Police District 1–5 El Belén
column7: Police District 1–6 La Granja and Police District 1–7 San Francisco.  For 2011
column8: the Secretary of Security designated L.2.162 billion (US$114.283 million) to law enforcement and criminal investigation in the Central District.

column1: As established by the Law on Police and Social Coexistence (Ley de Policía y Convivencia Social)
column2: municipalities can fund their own municipal police (Policía Municipal) and the Central District operates a Municipal Police force of 160 officers.  The Municipal Department of Justice (Departamento Municipal de Justicia) through its Municipal Police Court (Juzgado de Policía Municipal) enforces and prosecutes local law offenses.

column1: The Public Ministry (Ministerio Público) is the district attorney with nationwide jurisdiction in charge of prosecuting crimes on behalf of the people.  It is also headquartered in the Central District and maintains regional prosecution offices throughout the country.  The Attorney General of the Republic (Procuraduría General de la República) is the country's chief legal representative and prosecutes crimes on behalf of the state.
== Education ==
Tegucigalpa serves as the national education center
column2: hosting most of the universities and higher education institutions in the country.  For 2011
column3: the national government allocated L. 9.175 billion (US$484.9 million) of the national public education budget (equal to 42.1 percent of total) to the Central District.

column1: The public and private education system in Tegucigalpa is divided into 16 school districts (distritales).  All districts are part of the Departmental Directorate of Education (Dirección Departamental de Educación)
column2: which in turn is a part of the country's Secretary of Education.There are 1
column3: 235 public schools in the Central District broken down as 488 preschools
column4: 563 elementary schools
column5: and 184 middle and high schools.  In 2003
column6: there were a total of 287
column8: 915 in preschool
column10: 679 in elementary school

column1: The literacy rate
column2: as of 2011
column3: is at 80%.

column1: === Private schools ===
There are about 147 bilingual schools in Tegucigalpa.  The American School of Tegucigalpa (K-12)
column2: Discovery School (K-12)
column3: DelCampo International School (K-12)
column4: La Estancia School (K-11) and International School of Tegucigalpa (K-12
column5: Christian) are considered the most expensive private schools of the city. Total K-12 tuition of The American School of Tegucigalpa costs a total of L.1.366 million (US$72
column6: 248) for all years (amount based on 10–11 academic year). These private schools are highly recognized by American institutions such as the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools (SACS-CASI) and the American School of Tegucigalpa is the only one that has the International Baccalaureate (IB Program). Most of their students study abroad. Other popular private/bilingual schools include Elvel School (K-11)
column8: secular)
column9: La Estancia School (K-11)
column10: Shadai School (K-11

column1: There are two modalities in regards to the school calendar: American Period (August to July)
column2: mostly used by private and bilingual schools; and Latin Period (February to November)
column3: used by public schools.

column1: === Universities ===
There are 12 universities in Tegucigalpa
column2: including three state-funded higher education institutions.The National Autonomous University of Honduras (UNAH)
column3: founded in 1847
column4: is the country's most important university and operates eight regional campuses in several other cities in the country: UNAH-Valle de Sula
column5: UNAH-La Ceiba
column6: UNAH-Comayagua
column8: UNAH-Choluteca
column9: UNAH-Juticalpa
column10: UNAH-Valle del Aguán
column11: and University Technological Center UNAH–Danlí.  It employs 4
column12: 980 people throughout its campuses at an average annual salary of L.241

column1: The other two publicly funded institutions are Francisco Morazán National Pedagogic University (UPNFM)
column2: founded in 1989
column3: focusing on preparing future educators in several disciplines
column4: and the National Institute of Professional Formation (INFOP)
column5: founded in 1972
column6: focusing on economic and social development disciplines.  The National University of Agriculture (UNA)
column8: also state-funded and located in Catacamas
column9: Olancho
column10: maintains a liaison office in Tegucigalpa.

column1: There are 10 private universities in Tegucigalpa:
There are also two higher education centers: the Technological University Center (CEUTEC)
column2: part of UNITEC; and Guaymura University Center (CUG)
column3: founded in 1982.

column1: == Transportation ==
All barrios and colonias in Tegucigalpa can be accessed by automobile
column2: although some neighborhoods in the city suffer from unpaved
column3: narrow
column4: or hilly streets making them difficult to maneuver.  A grid of surface streets and a network of major avenues and boulevards cross through the major areas of the capital.  However
column5: the most transited roads suffer from heavy traffic congestion due to the region's geography and disorganized urbanization.

column1: An estimate of 400
column2: 000 vehicles take on the city streets and roads every day.  The oldest districts were not built with the advent of the automobile in mind and therefore lack efficient roadways to accommodate the overwhelming number of vehicles.  Newer developments
column3: such as the malls
column4: have been built with the car in mind allowing for large parking lots to accommodate their visitors.  In the last decades
column5: several of the boulevards and avenues have been retrofitted with grade separations to ease up the flow of traffic.

column1: === Roads and highways ===
The Secretariat of Public Works
column2: Transport and Housing (Honduras) (SOPTRAVI) presently divides the country's highway network into international routes (ruta internacional)
column3: national routes (ruta nacional)
column4: and provincial routes (ruta vecinal).  These are assigned numbers; however
column5: they are more often identified using their physical destinations (e.g. Tegucigalpa-Danlí highway) rather the number itself since road signage is scarce.

column1: International routes are given a "CA-" designation followed by a highway number (i.e. CA-1) that can be of one or two digits enclosed in a highway shield.  "CA-" highways are part of the Central American highway network (hence the "CA" letters) that interconnects Honduras with its neighboring countries as part of the Pan-American Highway.  National highways are assigned a two or three-digit number and provincial routes are assigned a three-digit number.
==== Arterial roads ====
The Anillo Periférico (beltway or ring road) and Boulevard Fuerzas Armadas (Armed Forces Blvd) are the city's two expressways—equipped with center dividers
column2: interchanges
column3: overpasses and underpasses—allowing for controlled-access traffic.  These connect with the city's other major boulevards: Central America Blvd
column4: Suyapa Blvd
column5: European Community Blvd
column6: and Kuwait Blvd—which are essentially limited-access roadways as they have been equipped with interchanges but may lack underpasses or overpasses to bypass crossing surface road traffic.

column1: Despite a network of major highways
column2: none reach directly into the historic downtown
column3: forcing drivers to rely heavily on surface streets.  Like in most Central American cities
column4: orientation and driving may be difficult to first-time visitors due to the nature of how streets are named
column5: insufficient road signage and the natives' driving behavior.  The city administration has green lit several road infrastructure projects to help reduce traffic congestion and improve the overall aspect of the city.List of major thoroughfares in the Central District
column6: including urban core arteries and outskirt roads:

column1: === Public transportation ===
Public transportation in Tegucigalpa and Comayagüela is based on buses and taxis
column2: covering 71 percent of the capital's road migration.  Bus routes are named based on the neighborhood they cover.  For example
column3: routes that travel from the downtown area to UNAH are labeled Centro-UNAH or Centro-Multiplaza-UNAH.  Taxis are the quickest way to move around the city after personal auto transportation.  Taxis are popular for short-distance trips or trips that require a sense of urgency.  Taxis are relatively cheap for the international tourist.  They are not the cheapest form of public transportation for the locals
column4: however.  There are over 12
column5: 000 taxis in the Central District.

column1: The public transportation system in Tegucigalpa is
column2: however
column3: highly disorganized.  Being a for-profit business
column4: it encourages competition between the fleet owners where revenue is the priority while ignoring the quality and efficiency of the service.  Public transportation regulation is very flawed.  Bus drivers must compete for passengers in order to bring the highest earnings possible while becoming a hazard for other drivers and pedestrians and contributing to traffic jams.  There is an overflow of public transportation vehicles on the roads.  The government has declared its public transportation system to be oversupplied and inefficient.There is a project under construction to give the public transportation system an upgrade with the addition of a bus rapid transit fleet.  In late May 2011
column5: the National Congress approved the project under a new law as part of the financing deal with the Inter-American Development Bank (IAB). The BRT system will be solely managed by the Central District government.

column1: === National and international ground transportation ===

Tegucigalpa is connected with the rest of the country through its city to city bus services.  There are several bus lines connecting the capital with the rest of Honduras. There is no central bus terminal in the city; in turn
column2: there are several bus stations scattered throughout the city
column3: particularly in Comayagüela
column4: and some of these stations are operated directly by the bus company serving from there.  Tegucigalpa is connected with the rest of Central America and Mexico through its international bus lines.  Buses leave for Guatemala
column5: El Salvador
column6: Nicaragua
column8: Panama and Mexico every day.

column1: === Air transportation ===
Toncontín International Airport (IATA: TGU
column2: ICAO: MHTG)
column3: serves as the main airport in and out of Tegucigalpa.  It is served by three domestic airlines and six international airlines connecting the capital to three cities in the United States and four cities in Central America as well as four cities within Honduras.The airport is frequently criticized as being dangerous; due to its location next to a sierra
column4: short runway
column5: and difficult approach. Large commercial jets are required to execute a tight hairpin left turn at very low altitude to land on the short runway. International airline pilots flying into Toncontín receive additional training for the Toncontín approach.

column1: Toncontín has been improved by the work of the Airport Corporation of Tegucigalpa (CAT)
column2: which is owned by TACA of El Salvador.  It is managed by InterAirports
column3: the company hired by the government of Honduras to manage the four airports in the country.The airport authority and the government of Honduras resumed airport relocation talks in April 2011 and announced that work on the new Palmerola airport would start by the fall of 2011 after years of efforts to replace Toncontín International with an airport at Palmerola in Comayagua where the Soto Cano Air Base is located.  However
column4: in a September 25
column5: 2011 update
column6: President Lobo stated officials were still "evaluating the pros and cons" of constructing the new airport.  This comes three years after former President Manuel Zelaya had announced that all commercial flights would be transferred to Soto Cano Air Base; however
column7: work on the new terminal at Soto Cano was then cancelled after Zelaya was removed from office on 28 June 2009 in the 2009 Honduran coup d'état.  Upon realization of the Palmerola airport
column8: international flights to and from Toncontín would continue to operate but would be limited to small aircraft.
